segments.speaker: Sarah Chen
segments.text: Good morning everyone! Let's dive into our Q1 API architecture review. We have a lot to cover today.

segments.speaker: Sarah Chen
segments.text: First up, we need to decide between GraphQL and REST for our new microservices. Marcus, can you share your research?

segments.speaker: Marcus Johnson
segments.text: Sure! I've been evaluating both approaches. GraphQL gives us more flexibility with data fetching, but it adds complexity to our backend.

segments.speaker: Priya Patel
segments.text: From the frontend perspective, GraphQL would significantly reduce the number of API calls we make. That's a huge win for performance.

segments.speaker: Chen Wei
segments.text: We need to consider the infrastructure implications. GraphQL servers require different caching strategies.

segments.speaker: Marcus Johnson
segments.text: I propose we go with GraphQL Federation. It gives us the benefits of GraphQL while allowing teams to own their own schemas.

segments.speaker: Sarah Chen
segments.text: That sounds promising. Let's see a quick diagram of how that would work. Marcus, can you share your screen?

segments.speaker: Elena Rodriguez
segments.text: Wait, I'm not clear on how service boundaries would work in this model. Can we zoom in on that part?

segments.speaker: Marcus Johnson
segments.text: Good question. Each service would expose its own GraphQL schema, and the gateway federates them. Let me explain more...

segments.speaker: Sarah Chen
segments.text: This makes sense. I'll create an RFC for the GraphQL schema design approach. Can I get that done by next week?

segments.speaker: Sarah Chen
segments.text: Everyone agrees? Great, let's move forward with GraphQL Federation as our architecture choice.

segments.speaker: David Kim
segments.text: I'll need to update our testing strategy to handle GraphQL queries. That should take about a week.

segments.speaker: Sarah Chen
segments.text: Perfect. Thanks everyone, great discussion today. Let's reconvene next Monday to review the RFC.
